content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. On the left, there are several pieces of fibro-adipose tissue, one of which contains a significant amount of hemorrhage/blood clot. On the right, there are at least four to five distinct, ovoid to irregular nodules with a dense, basophilic (dark purple) appearance, embedded in adipose (fat) tissue. These nodules are highly suggestive of lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed on one of the distinct basophilic nodules on the right, which is morphologically consistent with a lymph node. Given the clinical context of colorectal cancer, the primary task is to identify lymph node metastasis. I would systematically examine each potential lymph node for the presence of tumor cells. This particular node is selected for closer inspection to assess its architecture and cellular composition to determine if it is a positive (metastatic) or negative lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal in this case is to identify all lymph nodes and screen them for metastatic cancer. The dense, dark purple areas are the locations of lymphoid tissue. I would systematically examine each of these areas. The area highlighted by the green box is one of the most prominent and dense lymphoid aggregates on the slide, making it a high-priority target for examination to determine if it is a lymph node and if it contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task when examining lymph nodes in a cancer case is to identify any metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box corresponds to one of the ovoid tissue fragments that I identified as a potential lymph node. This specific node has a large, solid, and intensely basophilic region, which is a classic low-power feature suggesting that the normal lymphoid architecture has been replaced by a tumor deposit. Therefore, I would zoom into this area to confirm the presence of metastatic carcinoma and assess its characteristics. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The primary task for lymph nodes in a cancer case is to identify metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is within one of the most suspicious-looking lymph nodes on the slide. It's a densely cellular, dark blue region that strongly suggests the normal lymph node architecture has been replaced by an infiltrate. I would zoom into this specific area to confirm at high magnification whether these are malignant cells, to assess their morphology (e.g., glandular formation typical of colorectal adenocarcinoma), and to see if the tumor is extending beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat (extranodal extension). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area because it is located within one of the tissue fragments that I've identified as a probable lymph node (the lowest of the main group on the right). At low power, while this node is predominantly composed of dark-staining lymphoid cells, there appears to be a subtle focal irregularity or a slightly paler area within the dense purple background. Such areas are suspicious and require high-power examination to differentiate between benign reactive changes (like a germinal center) and a cluster of metastatic tumor cells, which often appear as eosinophilic (pink) nests. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, round, basophilic cells that are extensively permeating and replacing the perinodal adipose tissue. The cells are monotonous and appear to be lymphocytes. The normal architecture of the lymph node is effaced. While there are no definite malignant glands or clusters of atypical epithelial cells visible in this specific field, the extensive infiltration of the surrounding fat by lymphoid tissue is highly abnormal. This could represent a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic tumor that mimics lymphocytes, or a massively reactive process, or even a lymphoma. Careful examination of the entire node at higher magnification is required to search for definitive metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, dark, round cells (lymphocytes) replacing and infiltrating the surrounding mature adipose tissue (the large white circular spaces). This confirms the tissue is a lymph node with lymphoid tissue extending into the perinodal fat. I am carefully searching for nests, clusters, or glands of atypical epithelial cells which would signify metastatic adenocarcinoma. Based on this field of view, the infiltrate appears to be composed entirely of lymphoid cells. I do not see any definite evidence of metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node negative for metastasis, though the entire node must be examined to make a final determination.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node embedded in adipose tissue. A large, cohesive aggregate of malignant cells has replaced a significant portion of the normal lymphoid tissue. The tumor cells are arranged in crowded, poorly-formed glandular structures and solid nests. They exhibit features of malignancy, including enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a large deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, my suspicion is confirmed. The lower two-thirds of the image are occupied by a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells with large, dark, pleomorphic nuclei and irregular nuclear contours. These features are characteristic of metastatic carcinoma. The normal lymphocyte population is almost entirely effaced. Crucially, at the top of the image, these malignant cells are clearly seen infiltrating into the mature adipose tissue, indicating extranodal extension. My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma and definite extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the background is composed of a dense sheet of small, dark lymphocytes, confirming this is lymphoid tissue. Interspersed are clear spaces, which are adipocytes (fat cells). Critically, in the upper central part of the image, there is a distinct, cohesive cluster of large, atypical cells. These cells have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, irregular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. They are clearly different from the surrounding lymphocytes. This cluster represents metastatic carcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma.
